Award.AwardTitle: Networking and Engaging in Computer Science and Technology in Northern New Jersey

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
This project is designed to bring together Montclair State University (MSU), Saint Peter's University (SPU), and Seton Hall University (SHU) to collaborate and enable students who have demonstrated academic ability to pursue a Master's Degree in Computer Science. Computer science students as well as those students who have majored in other science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM) and non-STEM fields are eligible for the scholarships. As partner institutions, SPU and SHU are participating with the university in supporting and mentoring students. The program is using a seminar series to strengthen the collaboration among the participating institutions and pursuing collaborations with other schools in the region.

Intellectual Merit: The scholarship program is designed to serve as a model and structure for small geographical regions where multiple institutions service diverse populations. It is also strengthening the ties between these regional institutions so that these institutions can combine their strengths to better serve the student population. The program team consists of seven faculty members, five from MSU, one from SHU and one from SPU. All team members bring significant experiences in advising and mentoring students to the project.

Broader Impacts: The program is mentoring and supporting students through their graduate studies in computer science, many of whom are women and under-represented minorities. It is also offering opportunities to students from non-STEM backgrounds, since the program is considering strong candidates from non-CS backgrounds for the program. With 40% of New Jersey students leaving the state for post-secondary education, there is a significant need for programs in state to service the college student pool, so that the top talent invests in the region. Results are being disseminated at appropriate computer science conferences and journals as well as at the annual New Jersey Academy of Sciences (NJAS) meeting. The NJAS meeting is also serving as a platform for recruiting more institutions into the collaboration.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The Networking and Engaging in Computer Science and Information Technology Program

(NECST) has aimed to increase transition from any discipline into a computer science M.S. at Montclair State University (MSU). NECST students have come primarily from a consortium of northeastern NJ institutions: MSU, Seton Hall University (SHU), Saint Peter’s University (SPU), and William Paterson University (WPU).

The NSF S-STEM initiative was designed to increase STEM enrollment and to increase and improve the STEM workforce, particularly in computing. Among S-STEM programs, NECST is unusual in focusing on a graduate pathway. Its twofold objective has been to encourage students from computing or mathematics to strengthen their knowledge and credentials, and to interest those from other disciplines, perhaps coming late to an interest in computing or to a sense of career opportunities, into considering a future in technology, perhaps blended with their prior background and interests.h

The latter transitions are however neither uncommon nor easy. According to NSF Data Sets, over 17% of the science workforce comes from outside STEM--25% in computing. Yet, although graduate study has clear knowledge and career advantages, students may see academic and financial obstacles, including postponing full-time employment. These difficulties are compounded for transitioning students, facing up to a year of pre-requisite courses in mathematics and computer science. Moreover, many may worry, even with impressive soft skills, about “fitting into” a new discipline, with its own intellectual demands and perspective. In northeastern NJ, this is compounded by a high cost of living, with additional issues facing students from underrepresented populations or first-generation students, or those with financial challenges or family responsibilities, even given a computing or mathematics background.

NECST has dealt with these challenges through a combination of scholarships and support including advising, mentoring, and (often student-organized) group meetings and activities. In addition, working with MSU’s Career Center and Department of Computer Science, NECST has offered advice and assistance in finding degree- and career-relevant internships or part-time employment. There has also been an emphasis throughout on “soft skills” — critical thinking, communication, teamwork, and leadership.

The program has been a success. A total of 33 students have received $10,000 per year scholarships—17 (68%) students from other undergraduate majors (including non-STEM fields such as Asian Studies, History, Philosophy, and Psychology), 11 (42%) from consortium institutions, and 10 (38%) from underrepresented groups. Based on student applications and later feedback, many only considered graduate study in computing after learning about NECST, and overall student feedback has been uniformly positive. Of these 33 students, 24 (75%) had received MS degrees by May 2019, 5 (15%) are still pursuing graduate study, and 4 (12%) have left the program for academic and/or personal reasons.

All graduating students were employed in their chosen career within six months of graduation; several others left NECST program with enhanced technical and soft skills acquired during the pre-requisite program, able to accept full-time computing employment while continuing graduate studies part-time.

NECST has also succeeded increasing cooperation and collaboration among its partners, and between computer science and other departments and offices. Faculty from partner other institutions have been involved in program activities and in joint research, including cross-institution research with undergraduate and graduate students. MSU and SHU faculty have given NECST-related research and recruitment presentations at partner institutions. At SHU, the Department of Psychology has seen this as an opportunity for students to pursue alternative career paths and strengthen data science skills. Other departments and career centers at consortium institutions may now suggest graduate study in computing, with advice and support for pursuing that pathway. The success of NECST also inspired MSU’s Chemistry & Biochemistry Department to create OPEN-NJ.

Research output has included two posters and two papers will be submitted in the next year on the premises and results of the program.

Difficulties have included maintaining a cohort structure (due to early employment), and involving more faculty. A more formal structure for emphasizing integration of technical and soft skills would have further enriched the program.

In sum, NECST has brought together students from diverse undergraduate and social backgrounds. This diversity appears to have improved team and course quality, has supported introduction of multiple perspectives and emphasis on integrating soft skills and technical knowledge, and has arguably better prepared students for careers in computing or related areas. It also has encouraged collaboration among diverse faculty, benefitting faculty, students, and institutions.

 Publications:

[1] K.G. Herbert, T.J. Marlowe, J.A. Fails, C.S. Ku, K.M. Goedert, E. Hill, N.M. Goodey, D.T. MacVeigh. “The NECST Program - Networking and Engaging in ComputerScience and Information Technology Program”, 2017 ASEE Annual Conference andExposition, Columbus, OH, June 2017. 

[2] K.G. Herbert-Berger, N, Goodey,S. Ruczszyk, S. Kight, T.J. Marlowe. "Infusing CS Graduate Transition Curriculum with Professional, Technical and Data Science Competencies", Proceedings of the 50th ACM Technical Symposium on Computer Science Education, Minneapolis, MN, February 2019.


Last Modified: 08/30/2019
Modified by: Katherine Herbert

NECST students have come primarily from a consortium of northeastern NJ institutions: MSU, Seton Hall University (SHU), Saint Peter?s University (SPU), and William Paterson University (WPU). The NSF S-STEM initiative was designed to increase STEM enrollment and to increase and improve the STEM workforce, particularly in computing. Among S-STEM programs, NECST is unusual in focusing on a graduate pathway. Its twofold objective has been to encourage students from computing or mathematics to strengthen their knowledge and credentials, and to interest those from other disciplines, perhaps coming late to an interest in computing or to a sense of career opportunities, into considering a future in technology, perhaps blended with their prior background and interests.h The latter transitions are however neither uncommon nor easy. In northeastern NJ, this is compounded by a high cost of living, with additional issues facing students from underrepresented populations or first-generation students, or those with financial challenges or family responsibilities, even given a computing or mathematics background. NECST has dealt with these challenges through a combination of scholarships and support including advising, mentoring, and (often student-organized) group meetings and activities. There has also been an emphasis throughout on "soft skills" — critical thinking, communication, teamwork, and leadership. The program has been a success. A total of 33 students have received $10,000 per year scholarships—17 (68%) students from other undergraduate majors (including non-STEM fields such as Asian Studies, History, Philosophy, and Psychology), 11 (42%) from consortium institutions, and 10 (38%) from underrepresented groups. Based on student applications and later feedback, many only considered graduate study in computing after learning about NECST, and overall student feedback has been uniformly positive. Of these 33 students, 24 (75%) had received MS degrees by May 2019, 5 (15%) are still pursuing graduate study, and 4 (12%) have left the program for academic and/or personal reasons. All graduating students were employed in their chosen career within six months of graduation; several others left NECST program with enhanced technical and soft skills acquired during the pre-requisite program, able to accept full-time computing employment while continuing graduate studies part-time. A more formal structure for emphasizing integration of technical and soft skills would have further enriched the program.
